skills.name: Represent positive unit fractions on a number line
Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain
Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1

explanations.A: Convert ⅕ to a decimal: ⅕ = 2/10 = 2 ÷ 10 = 0.2. There are 10 marks in total, which takes us to 1, so each mark is 1 ÷ 10 = 0.1, making A the correct position for 0.2 or ⅕.
explanations.B: Not quite. Try to think about an equivalent fraction to ⅕ with a denominator of 10, and this may help you correctly locate its position on the number line: ⅕ = ?/10.
explanations.C: Not quite, ⅕ is not 0.5. Try to think about an equivalent fraction to ⅕ with a denominator of 10, and this may help you correctly locate its position on the number line: ⅕ = ?/10.
explanations.D: Not quite. Try to think about an equivalent fraction to ⅕ with a denominator of 10, and this may help you correctly locate its position on the number line: ⅕ = ?/10.

explanations.A: I think you went up 1 dash because of the 1 in the numerator Try to think about an equivalent fraction to ⅕ with a denominator of 10, and this may help you correctly locate its position on the number line: ⅕ = ?/10.
explanations.B: Convert ⅕ to a decimal: ⅕ = 2/10 = 2 ÷ 10 = 0.2. There are 10 marks in total, which takes us to 1, so each mark is 1 ÷ 10 = 0.1, making B the correct position for 0.2 or ⅕.
explanations.C: Not quite, ⅕ is not 0.5. Try to think about an equivalent fraction to ⅕ with a denominator of 10, and this may help you correctly locate its position on the number line: ⅕ = ?/10.
explanations.D: This would be 5/5. Try to think about an equivalent fraction to ⅕ with a denominator of 10, and this may help you correctly locate its position on the number line: ⅕ = ?/10.

explanations.A: Triangle numbers are patterns of dots arranged in a triangle, 1, 3, 6... Therefore we have a number that is both even and a triangle number, so they can't be mutually exclusive.
explanations.B: Triangle numbers are patterns of dots arranged in a triangle, 1, 3, 6... Therefore we have a number that is both a multiple of 3 and a triangle number, so they can't be mutually exclusive.
explanations.C: Triangular numbers are 1, 3, 6 ... The number 4 is not in this list, so both a 4 and a triangular number cannot occur at the same time.
explanations.D: Even numbers are 2, 4, 6 ... Don't forget, the question is asking which two events CANNOT happen at the same time.

explanations.A: Prime numbers only have 2 factors, so the primes are 2, 3, 5 .... Therefore we have a number that is both even and prime number, so they can't be mutually exclusive.
explanations.B: Rolling a number less than 3' gives possible answers of 1 and 2. This means that this option could not happen at the same time as rolling a 5.
explanations.C: Rolling a number less than 3' gives possible answers of 1 and 2. This means that we can have a number that is less than 3 that is also even, so these are not mutually exclusive.
explanations.D: Prime numbers only have 2 factors, so the primes are 2, 3, 5 .... Therefore we have a number that is both less than 3 and prime number, so they can't be mutually exclusive.

explanations.A: I think you've the right idea, but may have made a place value error. Check by adding 0.02 and 0.8.
explanations.B: You possibly think these probabilities are the same, but take as a starting point the fact that the sum of the probabilities of all possibilities must equal 1. In this question, the event either happens or it doesn't.
explanations.C: It looks as though you've multiplied the probability given in the question by 10. Take as a starting point the fact that the sum of the probabilities of all possibilities must equal 1. In this question, the event either happens or it doesn't
explanations.D: There are two possible outcomes here: either the event happens or it doesn't. Since the sum of the probabilities of all possibilities must equal 1, we have 0.02 + probability of event not happening = 1, and so 1 − 0.02 = probability of event not happening = 0.98.

explanations.A: There are two possible outcomes here: either the event happens or it doesn't. Since the sum of the probabilities of all possibilities must equal 1, we have 0.08 + probability of event not happening = 1, and so 1 − 0.08 = probability of event not happening = 0.92.
explanations.B: I think you've the right idea, but may have made a place value error. Check by adding 0.08 and 0.2.
explanations.C: You possibly think these probabilities are the same, but take as a starting point the fact that the sum of the probabilities of all possibilities must equal 1. In this question, the event either happens or it doesn't!
explanations.D: It looks as though you've multiplied the probability given in the question by 10. Take as a starting point the fact that the sum of the probabilities of all possibilities must equal 1. In this question, the event either happens or it doesn't!

explanations.A: I think you may have had the right idea but you made a mistake subtracting the fraction. Thinking of 1 as being 11/11 may help.
explanations.B: You might be thinking that because there are three events, each has probability of one-third, but this isn't the case because we're told that winning has a probability of 3/11, and so does drawing a game. What does this make the total probability of winning or drawing? This may help you to think about the only other possibility, that of losing.
explanations.C: The probability of winning or drawing is the sum of each probability, so 3/11 + 3/11 = 6/11. As there is only one other option (losing) and the probabilities add to 1, we can say that the probability of losing = 1 − 6/11 = 11/11 − 6/11 = 5/11.
explanations.D: You may think that the probabilities are the same, but we know that there are just these three options: win, lose or draw, so they must add to give 1. Does 3/11 + 3/11 + 3/11 equal 1? What could you change the lose probability to in order to give an answer of 1?

explanations.A: I think you have had the right idea but subtracting the fractions may have been an issue. Thinking of 1 as being 5/5 for this question may help.
explanations.B: You may think that the probabilities are the same, but we know that there are just these three options: win, lose or draw, so they must add to give 1. Does 2/5 + 2/5 + 2/5 equal 1? What could you change the lose probability to in order to give an answer of 1?
explanations.C: You might be thinking that because there are three events, each has probability of one-third, but this isn't the case because we're told that winning has a probability of ⅖, and so does drawing a game. What does this make the total probability of winning or drawing? This may help you to think about the only other possibility, that of losing.
explanations.D: The probability of winning or drawing is the sum of each probability, so ⅖ + ⅖ = ⅘. As there is only one other option (losing) and the probabilities add to 1, we can say that the probability of losing = 1 − ⅘ = 5/5 − 4/5 = ⅕.

explanations.A: Probabilities cannot be greater than 1. They can be zero if there's zero chance of something happening, and otherwise lie between these values. We could sum up this sentence very neatly as 0 ≤ probability ≤ 1.
explanations.B: Have a look closely at the numerator and denominator of the fraction, remembering that a probability of 1 is a certainty.
explanations.C: I think you've recognised that 0.5 is less than 1, but take care with signs - you can't have a negative probability.
explanations.D: Remember - a probability of 1 is a definite event, so a certainty. Would a probability greater than this value be possible?

explanations.A: Remember - a probability of 1 is a definite event, so a certainty. Would a probability greater than this value be possible?
explanations.B: I think you've recognised that 0.2 is less than 1, but take care with signs - probabilities can't be negative
explanations.C: Probabilities cannot be greater than 1. They can be zero if there's zero chance of something happening, and otherwise lie between these values. We could sum up this sentence very neatly as 0 ≤ probability ≤ 1.
explanations.D: Remember - a probability of 1 is a definite event, so a certainty. Would a probability greater than this value be possible?
